III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section
Description
1

(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following: (a) Routine
and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth (13) is an MCI state ward placed at Wolverine Center. He
is recovering from having surgery on both of his legs. Starting on
Friday, 11/1/2024, he began asking to see the health coordinator
at Wolverine Center because his leg bandages were coming off.
The coordinator is off work from Friday-Sunday, so this was not
possible. He was offered a visit to an urgent care facility today,
11/4/2024, but he refused to go. He had a regularly scheduled
medical appointment for 11/5/2024, but the doctor's office
rescheduled it for Thursday, 11/7/2024. He is not currently in any
pain, and he is able to obtain prescribed pain medication from
Wolverine Center as he needs it. There are no additional
concerns for the Youth.
Investigation Interviews
On 11/07/2024 the Complainant was interview but did not have
any additional information.
On 11/07/2024 an in-person meeting was held with Chief
Administrator (CA) at Wolverine. She was advised of the
allegations. CA advised that she was aware of the incident. She
reported that Youth A recently had surgery and has been healing
and recovering very well. She reported that Youth A had been
asking to speak with the health coordinator for three days,
however she was not available as she was off for jury duty on
Thursday and Friday of the end of the week. CA reported that she
believed that Health Coordinator had made contact with Youth A
on her last day of work prior to being off. She recalls that Youth A
had been in “a mood” and described that as not following
directives and verbally into it with everyone. CA stated that Youth
A was advised that the medical coordinator was off and asked
what his medical issue was, however he refused to respond. He
was also offered to go to urgent care, but refused. He denied that
he was in pain. She advised that Therapist was present and can
speak to behavior of Youth A. CA made note that when Youth A
was expressing his concerns he confirmed that the agency had
been responding to his requests for medication, meeting his
needs and providing everything that he needed. CA also advised
that Youth A was out of the building for a follow up appointment
from his leg surgery, but should be back within the hour.
2

On 11/07/2024 an interview was held with Youth B at Wolverine.
He denied having any medical needs that are not being met by the
agency. He stated he has never had to, but is aware of how to
request medical services. He reported that staff is advised and
then the request is escalated to a supervisor. He denied ever
requesting medical attention or services and being denied. He
also denied knowledge of Youth A or any other resident
requesting medical attention and not being provided services. He
reported feeling safe at the agency.
On 11/07/2024 an interview was held with Youth C at Wolverine.
He reported that he had a sore throat about a week ago, told staff
and he was taken to urgent care. He further reported he was
prescribed medication, which the agency got filled and gave it to
him as prescribed. He denied any incident of needing or
requesting medical attention and it was not provided. Youth C
denied knowledge of Youth A or any other resident that has
requested medical attention and it was not provided. He reported
feeling safe at the agency.
On 11/07/2024 an interview was held with Youth A at Wolverine.
He was returning from a medical appointment. When Youth A
entered the room he immediately stated he did not want to talk.
After some encouragement, Youth A agreed to answer three
questions for me. He indicated that he was feeling good, denied
he was in any pain and confirmed that the agency meets his
needs. Youth A then refused to answer any additional questions
and walked out of the interview room.
On 11/07/2024 an interview was held with Therapist. He reported
he was very familiar with Youth A. He recalled on Monday, Youth
A was escalated and was outside. Therapist reported he was in “a
mood” but did not say anything about being in pain or being
denied medical treatment. Therapist stated that Youth A
requested to call a concern into centralized intake and he was
escorted to make the telephone call. Therapist denied that he
asked Youth A why he wanted to call or what he was planning to
say and just took him to the office. Therapist and CA were present
when Youth A made the call. Therapist denied knowledge of a
time when Youth A or any other youth has requested medical
treatment and been denied. Therapist also explained that Health
Coordinator is not a nurse and just the coordinator of medical
services at the facility. Therapist stated that all youth are aware of
how to request medical services, which involves making the
request known to staff and supervisors. He denied that there is
any written process for youth to request medical services.
3

On 11/07/2024 an interview was held with Health Coordinator.
She reported that she took Youth A for initial surgery appointment
and was advised at discharge that the outer ace bandage could
be changed, but the other dressing should be changed at the first
follow up appointment. She recalled that she saw Youth A on
Wednesday 10/30/2024 for routine follow up. She reported she
advised him that she would be off Thursday and Friday and he did
not express any concerns at that time. Health Coordinator
reported that since the surgery, Youth A has been very active and
doing more than she and the staff believes is appropriate. She
provided examples of him walking over a mile to the 5th precinct
and playing basketball in the gym. She confirmed that the
recommendations from the Doctor at the time of discharge was
activity “as he tolerates it”. She denied that Youth A had any initial
concerns of pain. She reported he has received pain medication
as prescribed and noted as he was more active more pain
medication was requested by Youth A. She confirmed that the
medication was administered within the guidelines prescribed.
Health Coordinator reports the process to request medical
attention is to advise staff or supervisor. She noted that Youth A
did not make a request for medical treatment, but only requested
to see her as the Health Coordinator. On Monday 11/04/2024
when Health Coordinator returned to work, she recalled that Youth
A was upset and escalated because he was asking to see her and
she did not immediately respond. She noted she was doing the
scheduled med/pill count and staff told him that she would see him
later. She also reported that Shift Coordinator asked Youth A how
she could assist and he declined her assistance and remained
escalated, going around yelling and saying that staff would not
help him. When Health Coordinator was able to make contact with
Youth A and offered to take him to urgent care, he declined and
stated he would attend his upcoming follow up appointment. She
reported she has seen Youth A daily since Monday and he has
not expressed any concerns. She reported that his follow up
appointment went well and there were no noted concerns. Health
Coordinator denied knowledge of Youth A or any other youth
being denied medical treatment. She further denied that there is
any written request or process for youth to request medical
attention.
On 11/07/2024 a voicemail message was left for Foster Care
Worker requesting a return call with any concerns regarding the
agency.
4

On 12/17/2024 an interview was held with Shift Coordinator and
Staff 1. They both denied knowledge of Youth A or any other
resident requesting medical treatment and being denied.
Documents Reviewed:
DMC Discharge Instructions for Orthopedics form –
Documented surgery date as 10/21/2024 and procedure
performed as Tibia and Femur Hemiepiphysiodesis (guided
growth). This is a minimally invasive surgical procedure where a
tension-band plate (also called a guided growth plate) or a screw
called a percutaneous epiphysiodesis transphyseal screw
(abbreviated as PETS) is applied to a crooked bone to gradually
straighten it as a child or adolescent grows. Discharge paperwork
indicated Youth A could return to school on 10/23/2024, should
ambulate as tolerated, take pain medication as prescribed, keep
dressing clean and dry and return for follow up in two weeks.
DMC Return to School/Work Form – provided at scheduled
appointment on 11/07/2024. Indicated that Youth A could return
to school o 11/7/2024 (same day) and he should refrain from
contact sports for 2 weeks. It was also noted that Youth A could
return to full activity in 2 weeks, can play modified basketball in 2
weeks and he should refrain from aggressive running or jumping
at this time. No concerns or documentation of reports of pain
were noted.
Wolverine Human Services Medical/Dental Treatment Form –
Dated 11/7/2024. Documented the reason for visit is Orthopedic
follow up. Physician’s observations noted only a return for surgery
follow up and that hardware was in-tact. Physician’s
recommendations from appointment included patient to stop
crutches, can shower, no soaking in the tub for 4 to 6 weeks and
can return to all activities in 2 weeks. No running or jumping by
patient.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rules. Interviews were completed
with the youth, staff and Chief Administrator at the agency. As a
result, it was able to be assessed that the youth received
adequate medical treatment and requests for medical attention
were not ignored.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
5

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
